title: Projects
text: This is a selection of projects that I have worked on during my time as a DACSS student:

title: Projects
text:
DACSS 603: Introduction to Quantitative Analysis
For my final project, I analyzed data from the 2021 American Family Survey to examine whether the amount of time a person spends caring for their children on their own influences their support for a higher Child Tax Credit. The hypothesis was that people who spend more time caring for their children are more likely to support a higher Child Tax Credit. A linear regression model was used to analyze the data. No significant effect of childcare hours on support for a higher tax credit was observed in the results of this analysis.
603 Final Paper with Embedded Code
Interactive Dashboard Presentation

title: About Me
text:
I am currently finishing my final semester as a graduate student at UMass Amherst studying Data Analytics and Computational Social Science (DACSS), and I will graduate in February 2026. I previously received a bachelor’s degree in psychology from UMass Lowell in May 2022. When I was an undergraduate student, I enjoyed my classes on research and statistics, and I wanted to continue studying these topics in graduate school, which led me to the DACSS program at UMass Amherst.
For more information on my educational and professional experience, my resume can be viewed here.

title: 603 Final Project
text:
ggplotly(plot1)











This plot depicts the predicted outcomes for the suggested Child Tax Credit amount based on the number of hours a parent spends caring for their children on their own during a typical day. For every one-hour increase in time a parent spends caring for their children on their own during a typical day, their suggested Child Tax Credit decreases by around $1.08. This effect is not significant (p=0.922). These results do not support the hypothesis that people who spend more time caring for their children on their own are more likely to support a higher Child Tax Credit.
